and dosages not specifically listed here or on the NIH clinical guidelines
should be discussed with the infectious diseases service.***

If you cannot use the recommended antimicrobials or you believe another one
would be better for your patient, you can order another drug. Please indicate
the reason you need an alternative drug below.

prescribers to learn more about situations that need alternatives, improve the
CDSS, and in some cases offer suggestions.

ORZID GMENU ER/UC LYME DISEASE PROPHYLAXIS

Name.Text: Erythema migrans associated with Lyme disease

Name.Item: ORZID GMENU ER/UC LYME ACUTE NEURO DISEASE
Name.Text: Acute neurological disease associated with Lyme disease

Name.Item: ORZID GMENU ER/UC LYME CARDIAC DISEASE
Name.Text: Cardiac disease associated with Lyme disease
Lyme disease results from the transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi from an
Ixodes spp. tick bite. Patients who display signs of illness or fever within 30
days of removing an attached tick should be evaluated for tick-borne illness.
In the upper Midwest these are Lyme disease, human anaplasmosis, babesiosis, and
Powassan virus disease. Patients who have been bitten by an Ixodes spp. tick
(deer tick) but who do not display signs or symptoms of infection should not
Prophylactic antimicrobial treatment may be beneficial in certain patients who
have been bitten while in endemic areas.
Except for erythema migrans, Lyme disease is a complicated, difficult disease to
diagnose and treat. Infectious Diseases consultation is strongly encouraged.
Mandell Chapter: Lyme Disease (Lyme Borreliosis) Due to Borrelia burgdorferi
Minnesota Department of Health, Disease Control Newsletter (2006), 34.2:9-24

Name.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ACUTE SINUSITIS MILD TO MOD
Name.Text: [CLICK HERE] for treatment of mild to moderate bacterial sinusitis - Opt CDSS
[CLICK HERE] for treatment of severe bacterial sinusitis
Most cases of acute sinusitis are viral and resolve within 10 days. Symptoms
(nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, and tooth or facial pain) can be
treated with decongestants, analgesics, and nasal saline. Diagnosis of acute
sinusitis is based on the presence of at least 2 major or 1 major and at least 2
2. Purulent or discolored posterior nasal discharge
If patient meets criteria above for acute sinusitis, treat with antimicrobials
according to the following criteria for mild to moderate or severe bacterial
2. Double-sickening - Symptoms typical of viral upper respiratory infection
initially improving for 5-6 days then worsening with new development of fever,
Severe signs or symptoms of high fever (>/= 102 degrees Fahrenheit, >/= 39
degrees Celsius) and purulent nasal discharge for 3-4 consecutive days or facial
pain lasting for at least 3-4 consecutive days at the beginning of illness.
Chow et al, Clinical Infectious Diseases. 2012, 54(8) e72-e112
Meltzer et al, J Allergy Clin Immunol. 2004, 114(6) S155-S212.
Rosenfeld et al, Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Surgery. 2015, 152(4) 598-609
Sanford keyword: Sinusitis, Acute, Empiric Therapy
Up-To-Date article: Acute sinusitis and rhinosinusitis in adults: Clinical

Name.Item: PSJIZID PIP/TAZO 3.375 GM IV ONCE ER/UC

Name.Text: Patients with an acutely inflamed appendix and no gangrene or perforation are
considered to have uncomplicated appendicitis. Patients with gangrene,
perforation, peritonitis, or abscess have complicated appendicitis. Treatment
with antibiotics is an option for patients who are unfit for surgery or refuse
surgery. Treatment with antibiotics should not be used routinely as an
Select for treatment of complicated appendicitis
($) [DI] infusion beginning 60 minutes before incision < OR >
STAT ($) [DI] infusion beginning 60 minutes before incision
Treatment of patients who are unfit for surgery or refuse surgery
Step down treatment after completion of initial intravenous treatment
Solomkin et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2010, 50:133-64
Up-to-Date article: Management of acute appendicitis in adults

Name.Item: ORZID GMENU ER/UC ABX GENERAL INFORMATION ED
ORZID GMENU ER/UC NOSO PNEUMONIA NEW

Name.Text: Aspiration of oropharyngeal or gastric contents induces inflammation and is
often accompanied by fever and/or an infiltrate. Bacterial pneumonia occurs in
a minority of patients who aspirate, typically about 3 days later. The patient
usually improves for the first 2 days and then worsens as bacterial pneumonia
develops with increased fever, new or progressive infiltrates, leukocytosis, and
Antimicrobials have no role for treatment of aspiration and their use entails
risk of side effects and selection of resistant organisms.
Antimicrobials used for community-acquired pneumonia are appropriate for cases
that develop after an episode of aspiration. For more information, consult
Treatment for patients with pneumonitis but without lung abscess or putrid
Therapy directed towards anaerobic pathogens is usually unnecessary. If
Treament for patients with LUNG ABSCESS
Refer to Lung and Mediastinum section of the inpatient or outpatient
Dennesen PJ Am J Respir Crit Care Med 2001, 163: 1371
Kalil AC et al. Clin Infect Dis 2016. 63:1

Once a diagnosis of acute bacterial meningitis is considered likely,
antimicrobials should be initiated as soon as possible after obtaining blood
cultures and performing a lumbar puncture to obtain cerebrospinal fluid. Adjust
antimicrobial regimen to optimize therapy and treatment duration based on
Intravenous dexamethasone therapy improves outcomes for meningitis with
Streptococcus pneumoniae and is recommended for empirical treatment of all
community acquired cases that might be associated with S. pneumoniae.
Dexamethasone must be given before (1 to 20 minutes) or concurrent with
If meningococcal meningitis is identified, antimicrobial prophylaxis should be
considered for close contacts. Contact Infectious Diseases/Epidemiology for
(Discontinue if isolated pathogen is not S. pneumoniae)

Treatment for Adults < 50 Years Without Alcoholism, Debilitating Disease, or
Any Other Condition Associated with Impaired Cellular Immunity.
Treatment for Adults >= 50 Years or With Alcoholism, Debilitating Disease, or
Impaired Cellular Immunity. Listeria Monocytogenes is One Important Pathogen.
